awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Power and Energy Conference at Illinois 2024 (PECI)
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel grant will provide opportunities to students for attending the fifteenth Annual Power and Energy Conference at Illinois (PECI) that will take place on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in April 2024. The student program of this conference will include paper presentations, tutorial sessions, and panel discussions. Networking events between students and power system researchers from industry and government laboratories are also planned. Special efforts will be made to encourage the participation of women and minority students.

PECI is the oldest annual, student-run IEEE international conference about power and energy technology. The conference is organized by the IEEE PES/PELS/IAS Joint Graduate Student Chapter at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and has become a perfect place in the Midwest for industry and academic researchers to discuss future power and energy topics such as renewable energy, electrified transportation, smart grid reliability, security of cyber-physical systems, and power electronics for emerging technologies. Attendees will get ample opportunities to present their research, and also learn about each other's work to have a broad perspective on ongoing topics in energy systems research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Power and Energy Conference at Illinois (PECI) is an annual conference bringing together experts in the power and energy field. Activities include keynotes, panel discussions, industry talks, paper sessions, and poster sessions on topics ranging from power systems and renewable energy to machines and power electronics. Each year, the PECI organizational committee seeks NSF aid to help more students have the opportunity to participate in the conference. For many students, PECI has been the first academic conference they have attended thanks to the aid they were able to receive. Not only do these students benefit from the invaluable networking, for many it is also their first chance to present their research to others in their field. Here, they are able to develop their communication skills and engage in valuable discussions about their work. 

 

By attending the 2024 PECI, students benefited from closer interactions with experts, professors, and industry professionals and received advice and mentorship for their future career. In addition to student technical presentations and posters, students learned about the mega-trends in power and energy and cutting-edge research from industry leaders and experts. In addition to the valuable keynote presentations, the conference also included talks from “young researchers,” allowing for the work of emerging researchers (such as newer faculty) to talk about their research and what they see as the future for the field of power and energy.

 

Support from NSF for student travel to PECI in 2024, enabled 17 participants from 11 different universities to learn from the conference experience by covering their registration, accommodation expenses and/or travel to and from the conference. 60% of these participants receiving NSF support were women or minorities.


Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Kiruba Haran
